prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Sensitivity Estimation: We aim for the same sensitivity as our Cycle 0 observations, namely an N2D+(3-2) line sensitivity of ~10 mJy over a 0.16 km/s velocity interval over a beam of 2.3". To estimate the total time, we first create a test "rectangular" mosaic with 85 pointings. Then we input 50 mK noise level and with everything else exactly the same, we get the on-source time for one pointing from OT. Next in our real proposal we tweak the noise level to match this time, so the total time should be what we desired. However, we note that this time is just a little over 6 scheduling blocks (SBs, bandpass calibrations), so that we end up with 7 SBs, which is a waste of efficiency. So we decide to sacrifice a little sensitivity to control the on-source time just within 6 scheduling blocks for the maximum efficiency, and the final one-pointing on-source time is 3.4 min (corresponding to ~ 52 mK or 12 mJy in the test rectangular mosaic). Finally the total time is 8.4 h (total time on-source 4.73 h, overhead time well below 30%) with 12 mJy sensitivity (in OT we input 20 mJy to consider mosaic overlap).
Our Cycle 0 observation showed that the cores have 0.8 km/s velocity width. The requested resolution is good enough to resolve the spectra.

Similar to our Cycle 0 observation, it is able to detect a few solar mass core, and the most massive cores have 7" diameter. The most compact array has angular resolution of 1.6", and maximum scale 11.6". These are sufficient for our purpose of building up a core mass function, especially at high mass end.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: RESUBMISSION OF CYCLE 2 B-RATED PROPOSAL, WITHDRAW IF COMPLETED IN CYCLE 2. Similarities between the shapes of the core mass function (CMF) and the stellar initial mass function have been noted, which may reveal a fundamental aspect of the star formation process. However, the relation of these "cores", typically observed via their dust continuum emission, and the pre-stellar cores (PSC) that will actually form stars is unclear. Here we propose to measure the PSC mass function by mapping N2D+(3-2) over a contiguous region of an IRDC that we have already observed in N2H+ with CARMA and in which we have already identified at least two relatively massive N2D+ PSCs with ALMA in Cycle 0. We expect to identify ~75 N2D+ cores, and measure masses via mm continuum emission, mid-infrared extinction and virial methods. We will carry out astrochemical modeling of the cores to estimate deuteration ages, which can help de-bias the observed PSC mass function to obtain the true PSC mass function. We will also study the chemical evolution from PSCs to protostellar cores. Finally, we will measure core-to-core kinematics and compare with simulations of molecular cloud turbulence.
